content.description: Stand start the slab to the left of the twin aretes. Using good little quartz knobs and a good seam for your feet pull onto the scooped face, crimp up knobs  until the exciting topout.
content.location: On the Bermuda Triangle Boulder, just to the left or the right leaning arete project.

content.description:
Sit start with a very low foot that is right off the ground and a heel up on the arete. Put your right hand on the  good starting hold and your left hand on one of the two other holds. Pull off the ground and reach up with your right hand to a small crimp in from the arete a little. Move your left foot onto a little chip and throw up the arete to a descent slopey full hand hold. bring your right foot up for another heel and bring your left hand up to the top of the triangle and work on rocking over the edge of the arete. It's a few tough moves for a fun problem. Might be a little more challenging for the tall climber. 

  Have fun
content.location: This climb is on the Bermuda Triangle boulder along with two other routes. Take the trail from the Fun boulder over to the Lower Cliff area, and you will see the triangular face just up and left of Smear Tactics.

content.description:
Smear Tactics lives up to it's name. Start on the far left side of the fin and work right until the lip becomes less juggy. Top out.  

  Smear Tactics is a good warmup and a good exercise in smearing on granite. It's probably about 5.7/5.8 in difficulty.

This is a super fun compression-style problem. Start with your right hand on the corner and your left on a sloping sidepull feature. Bump your right hand up the corner, and then surf the corner to a somewhat tall topout.
content.location: It's on the same boulder as Smear Tactics. Start on the far right side of said boulder.

content.description:
The Balance Dyno is the most unlikely of boulder problems. Start on the left corner of the steepest part of the Lower Wall.  

  Clamber up onto a ledge and throw a left toe-hook into the big horizontal crack. This should allow you to stand up straight.  Then grab a nothing crimp with your left hand, and jump up to a sloping ledge. Hold the considerable outward swing and match the ledge. The crux is getting your feet established on the wall and reaching for a crimp just below the lip.  

  The dyno is definitely a crowd-pleasing move, but getting established on the face after the dyno is incredibly awkward and maybe a bit height dependent.

The Lower Cliff sits down and left from The Hive. Despite the fact that it's about 20-25 feet tall and over 100 feet long, it might be difficult to find until you're right on it.  

  The Lower Cliff has some potential for cool problems. There's a steep face/boulder on the left, a less steep wall in the middle, and the Smear Tactics boulder on the right. There are also a few boulders right below the cliff that might have potential.
